Benjamin Franklin: “Democracy is two wolves and a lamb voting on what to have for lunch. Liberty is a well-armed lamb contesting the vote!”
to any band of regular troops.” An Examination of the Leading Principles of the Federal Constitution, October 10, 1787

Noah Webster: “Before a standing army can rule, the people must be disarmed, as they are in almost every country in Europe. The supreme power in America cannot enforce unjust laws by the sword; because the whole body of the people are armed, and constitute a force superior …

Thomas Jefferson: “What country can preserve its liberties if their rulers are not warned from time to time that their people preserve the spirit of resistance. Let them take arms.” Letter, 20 December 1787
Frederick Douglass: “A man's rights rest in three boxes. The ballot box, jury box and the cartridge box.” Speech 15 November 1867

Madison contrasted this 
American advantage of an armed citizenry with Europe, where governments were 
“afraid to trust the people with arms.” For European governments recognized 
an armed citizenry could not be conquered by the largest standing army that could be supported.

James Madison:  one of the “advantage[s]” that
“Americans possess over the people of almost every other nation” is the “advantage of being armed.” The Federalist No. 46, at 321

So “[t]he great object is, that every man 
be armed . . . . Every one who is able may 
have a gun.”

Patrick Henry: the people must “[g]uard with jealous attention the public liberty. Suspect every one who approaches that jewel. Unfortunately, nothing will preserve it but 
downright force. Whenever you give up that 
force, you are inevitably ruined.”

Joseph Story: “The right of the citizens to keep and bear arms has justly been considered, as the palladium of the liberties of a republic; since it offers a strong moral check against the usurpation and arbitrary power of rulers.”  Commentaries on the Constitution at 746 (1833)

Alexander Hamilton: “If the representatives of the people betray their constituents, there is then no resource left but in the exertion of that original right of self-defence, which is paramount to all positive forms of government.” The Federalist No. 28, at 178
George Mason: “[T]o disarm the people; that [is] the best and most effectual way to enslave them.”
